title: DoughFlow Wiki: Unveiling the World of Finance
content: Welcome to the DoughFlow Wiki, your comprehensive guide to understanding the fundamentals of stocks and unraveling the mysteries of candlestick graphs. Whether you're a seasoned investor or a curious novice, this wiki is your gateway to mastering the intricacies of the financial world.

title: Stocks: The Building Blocks of Finance
content: Stocks, also known as shares or equities, represent ownership in a company. When you purchase a stock, you become a shareholder, entitled to a portion of the company's profits and assets. Understanding the basics of stocks is crucial for navigating the financial markets effectively.

title: Stock Market
content: A marketplace where stocks are bought and sold. Major stock exchanges include the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) and the Nasdaq.

title: Stock Price
content: The current value of a single share of a company's stock, determined by supply and demand in the market.

title: Market Capitalization
content:
The total value of a company's outstanding shares, calculated by multiplying the stock price by the number of shares outstanding.
Dividends - Payments made by companies to shareholders as a share of their profits.

title: Candlestick Graphs: Illuminating Market Trends
content: Candlestick graphs are a popular tool used by traders and analysts to visualize price movements in the financial markets. Each candlestick represents a specific time period (e.g., one day) and provides valuable information about the open, high, low, and close prices of a security.

title: Candlestick
content: The rectangular shape formed by the open and close prices of a security during a specific time period. A filled (black or red) candlestick indicates a lower close price than the open, while a hollow (white or green) candlestick indicates a higher close price.

title: Wick or Shadow
content: The thin lines extending above and below the candlestick body, representing the highest and lowest prices reached during the time period.

title: Bullish and Bearish
content: A bullish candlestick indicates that the closing price is higher than the opening price, suggesting buying pressure. Conversely, a bearish candlestick indicates that the closing price is lower than the opening price, suggesting selling pressure.

title: Doji
content: A candlestick pattern characterized by a small body and wicks of equal length, indicating indecision in the market.

title: Hammer and Hanging Man
content: Single candlestick patterns with long lower wicks and small bodies, signaling potential reversals in the market.

title: Engulfing Pattern
content: A two-candlestick pattern where the second candlestick completely engulfs the body of the first candlestick, suggesting a reversal of the prevailing trend.
